fields.description:
The tests
* arrow-compute-scalar-test
** "TestCompareKernel.PrimitiveRandomTests"
* arrow-compute-vector-test
** "TestFilterKernelWithNumeric/3.CompareArrayAndFilterRandomNumeric"
** "TestFilterKernelWithNumeric/7.CompareArrayAndFilterRandomNumeric"

Fail on aarch64 on NixOS. Full Build log is attached.
fields.summary: [C++][Compute] Test failures with gcc-9.3 on aarch64

comments.body:
Thanks for the report. The output is difficult to read. Can you try again with {{ctest --output-on-failure}}?

Also, is this only on aarch64 or also on x86-64?

Sorry I don't have access to the test system or any other aarch64 system.

This is only on aarch64.
You mean there isn't a way to affect the build procedure or build options?

Note such errors were already reported in ARROW-6213, and most likely it was due to buggy compiler auto-vectorization. Another gcc version fixed the issue (though you're using a new gcc version still).

If you don't have the possibility to even change the compiler or compiler flags it will be difficult to diagnose this.

I reproduced this issue on one aarch64 server. As [~apitrou] commented, this bug is related to compiler.
 This bug occurs with gcc-9.3.0, same as build log from  [~tobim].
 I also tried gcc-7.5.0, everything is fine.
 Will do some deeper investigation when have time.

Steps to reproduce on ubuntu 18.04, aarch64

install gcc-9
https://askubuntu.com/questions/1140183/install-gcc-9-on-ubuntu-18-04

build
{code:bash}
$ cmake -GNinja -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Release -DARROW_BUILD_TESTS=ON -DARROW_COMPUTE=ON -DCMAKE_C_COMPILER=gcc-9 -DCMAKE_CXX_COMPILER=g++-9 ..
$ ninja
{code}

test
{code:bash}
$ release/arrow-compute-vector-test
...
[  FAILED  ] 2 tests, listed below:
[  FAILED  ] TestFilterKernelWithNumeric/3.CompareArrayAndFilterRandomNumeric, where TypeParam = arrow::UInt64Type
[  FAILED  ] TestFilterKernelWithNumeric/7.CompareArrayAndFilterRandomNumeric, where TypeParam = arrow::Int64Type

$ release/arrow-compute-scalar-test
...
[  FAILED  ] 1 test, listed below:
[  FAILED  ] TestCompareKernel.PrimitiveRandomTests
{code}
[~tobim], so I think this is not an Arrow bug. A quick fix is to switch the compiler to gcc-7 (maybe clang, gcc-8, ...).
Should you perhaps try to make a gcc bug report?
Sure. Will try to see if can produce a simple test code. Also ask some Arm compiler guys to see if they know something.

[~yibocai] I wouldn't be so sure without looking a bit deeper into this. An alternative explanation would be that some undefined behavior is exploited by the newer GCC, but the problem doesn't surface on amd64 because of its more forgiving memory model.
[~tobim], Arm relaxed memory model is unlikely to be the reason. I think all these unit tests are single threaded. Anyway, I will look into this issue.
As mentioned above, this already surfaced on AVX512 builds with some gcc versions. So it has nothing do with arm64 memory model.
Also note that we have UBSAN CI job that should hopefully catch undefined behaviour issues (though there's obviously no 100% guarantee about that).

Wrote a simple test program to reproduce this issue.
Details in gcc bug report: https://gcc.gnu.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=98949

To summarize:
- gcc-9.3 aarch64 auto vectorization generates buggy code for this [code block|https://github.com/apache/arrow/blob/d0ce28b7fdcfba16d8888e404e20eda47097df17/cpp/src/arrow/util/bitmap_generate.h#L89-L96].
- gcc-7.5, gcc-10.1 don't have this problem.

gcc community has backported tree-optimization patch to gcc-9 release branch. [1]
This bug will be fixed in gcc-9.4.
There may be some days before Ubuntu update their gcc release. I expect it will be soon.
Thanks [~tobim] to test and report this issue, it's actually a critical compiler bug that drives the community to backport according patches quickly.

[1] https://gcc.gnu.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=97236#c12
